title: UK's architectural elite hail the future of housing : a council estate in Norwich
text:
Could this be the moment council housing became fashionable again? The people who run British architecture seem to think so.

A council estate in Norwich has become the first development completely made up of social housing to be awarded this year’s prestigious Royal Institute Of British Architects' Stirling Prize for the UK’s best building.

In a move which the leading architectural body in the country hopes will herald a renaissance for social housing, and go towards helping solve the housing crisis, the Goldsmith Street estate was hailed by the judges as a “modest masterpiece”.

Instead of a cutting-edge glass and steel tower the judges chose a high density housing development incorporating the latest environmental design techniques to minimise its carbon footprint.

These include each of the two storey houses and apartment blocks facing south to maximise solar gain, every wall built over 600mm thick, and the roofs angled at 15 degrees to ensure each terrace does not block sunlight from homes in the street behind.

Even the smallest details have been considered with the environment in mind. Letterboxes are built into external porches rather than the front doors, to reduce draughts, while perforated aluminium ‘brise-soleils’ provide shade from the sun above windows and doors.
description: Could this be the moment council housing became fashionable again?
